Population in 1793 was 500, but has fallen since. The final three (of 11) confiscations from this place, all in 1789, were associated with the Parlement / Third Estate of Britanny, and further research may show other titles / editions are linked. Thus, this La Gravelle overwhelmingly likely and preferred over the historical commune of La Gravelle in Calvados, between Falaise and Lisieux (about 20 km from each), which is on the road from Caen to Versailles and Paris and is now part of the commune of Montviette. A smaller place now, the (Montviette) population in 1793 was 474.

name: TORCY
notes:
ID notes for Confiscations Registers data: This Torcy has been, since 1846, a quartier of Sedan: it has a presence in Wikipedia but its only presence in Geonames is the Bureau de Poste de Sedan Torcy, which reference has been used in this database, though the customs post was probably to the East by the river and bridge. Torcy was the crossing point for large numbers of books and especially regular consignments of periodicals from Bouillon and also sometimes Liege. These included important periodicals published in Bouillon, notably the Journal encyclopedique and Almanach Physico-Economique. Lutton, associated with most of these, lived in Paris. Evidence that Torcy was a key border point is found in a letter of the Bouillon publisher of the Journal Encyclopedique, Pierre Rousseau, to the bookseller-publisher-pirate Cazin, dated 12 April 1760, cited by Belin (Le commerces des livres prohibes a Paris, 1750-1789, pp. 48-9): 'A l'égard des nouveautés que vous voudriez avoir des pays étrangers, le sieur Weissembruck, directeur de mon 
bureau, pourra vous les procurer assez commodément, y ayant ici un messager, qui va directement à Charleville [a town a few miles inland, today part of Charleville-Mézières] sans passer par Sedan ni Torcy'. This leaves no doubt that the Torcy intended by all or most of the confiscation records is the border crossing rather than any other place.
